channel.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
channel.description:
This is to remain civil, i'm requesting a lock to my other topic "antivirus" so we can start over and just compare.
post the specs of your anti-virus of choice, and discuss.
[code]Exclusive McAfee Active Protection™ technology McAfee Active Protection™ technology instantly analyzes and blocks new and emerging threats in milliseconds, so there’s virtually no gap in your protection. Unlike the competition, threats are analyzed and blocked in milliseconds, so you don’t have to wait for regular updates to arrive.
Anti-Virus/Anti-Spyware Detects, blocks, and removes viruses, spyware, adware, even rootkits—insidious programs designed to tamper with your PC.
Two-Way Firewall Blocks outsiders from hacking into your PC.
McAfee® SiteAdvisor® Helps you know about a website's risks before you click to stop malware threats. Advanced phishing protection alerts you to websites that may try to steal your identity or gain access to your financial information. Provides site ratings in 22 popular search engines.
Scan Time Rely on real time scanning to automatically protect you against threats to your PC. Enjoy fast subsequent full system scan time which won’t slow you down.
Memory Utilization Small memory footprint means less impact on your day-to-day PC activity.
Installation Small download size enables you to quickly get up and running.
Home Screen Easily check the status of your protection, monitor how many threats have been blocked, and manage your security—all from the McAfee home screen.
Idle Timer & Scheduler Reserve security scans and updates for when you are not using your PC, for less disruptions.
Alert System Alerts are unintrusive and easy to understand
McAfee® QuickClean Safely removes junk files that slow down your PC.
McAfee® Shredder™ Digitally destroys no-longer-needed sensitive files to prevent anyone from accessing them.
Disk Defragmenter Get quick access to consolidate fragmented files and folders.
System Requirements Supported Operating Systems
•Windows XP (32-bit) with Service Pack 2 (SP2) or higher •Windows Vista (32-bit and 64-bit) •Windows 7 (32-bit and 64-bit) System Requirements
•1 GHz processor or higher •800 × 600 or higher resolution •256 MB RAM or higher for Windows XP (512 MB recommended) •512 MB RAM for Vista/Windows 7 (2GB recommended) •200 MB of available free drive space •Internet connection Supported Browsers
•Microsoft Internet Explorer 6.0 or later •Optional: Mozilla Firefox 2 or later [/code]

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

Fat Cookies:

Windows XP SP3: No anti-virus

Exact same for me, pirated Professional SP3 lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @laurent_248 laurent 248
item.description:
@laurent_248 wrote:

[quote=“Evil_, post:32, topic:382565”]I used to like AVG until I started programming with MASM32 and the dumbass was thinking the executables created were trojans… evidently it was because they were very small

If I were on windows, I would probably use avast or something idk, I generally am never on windows long enough to want to install an antivirus. I like arch linux too much.[/quote]

Naw avast suck. Malwarebytes looks nice.

Read full topic

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

I used to like AVG until I started programming with MASM32 and the dumbass was thinking the executables created were trojans… evidently it was because they were very small

If I were on windows, I would probably use avast or something idk, I generally am never on windows long enough to want to install an antivirus. I like arch linux too much.

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“laurent 248, post:29, topic:382565”]Commview+HiJackThis ftw btw. Just check if there’s something goin out of your comp to a no-ip on a suspect port and HiJackThis suspicious startup files…

This is one of the best method I found if you don’t want to be RAT by a fud (Fully UnDetected) RAT. ;)[/quote]
Good idea.

I actually have CommView and I also have Cain and Abel. That monitors packets coming in and out.

Read full topic

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

I use avast! for my anti-virus, Zonealarm for my firewall, and Spy-bot running once a month.

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @laurent_248 laurent 248
item.description:
@laurent_248 wrote:

Commview+HiJackThis ftw btw. Just check if there’s something goin out of your comp to a no-ip on a suspect port and HiJackThis suspicious startup files…

This is one of the best method I found if you don’t want to be RAT by a fud (Fully UnDetected) RAT.

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus

item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

I use a free antivirus that can be downloaded at http://fedoraproject.org/.

It stops more virus than any paid anti-virus software on the market, even $10000 ones.

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

Windows 7: Malware Bytes’ Anti-Malware PRO
I honestly prefer just regular Malware Bytes’ Anti-Malware. I don’t plan on ever using that program in it called File Assassin because I’m paranoid that the files you “assassinate” will actually get sent to them and stored somewhere for future reference.

Read full topic

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

AVG is horrible… I downloaded the 30-day free paid version trial shit, and when it expired, all it did was warn me how i had to buy it, but not with pop-ups, with hidden messages when you open it. Turns out, AVG stops protecting you after your 29 day trial and doesn’t automatically switch to the free version. Norton just bugs me with constant pop ups basically saying, “You have us downloaded, we will keep popping up until you buy our software!” with the options “Remind me in a hour” “Never remind me again”, when you select never remind me again, it pops up the next time you restart the computer.

Read full topic

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @Javafire Javafire
item.description:
@Javafire wrote:

ollie123:

I’m currently trialling BitDefender

i wouldn’t buy it, i found this, looks odd.

complaintsboard.com

Bitdefender

Purchase bit defender previously. Like product. At renewal time, recieved a notice from bit defender that I would automatically be renewed unliess I opted out, no amount stated. Vistied their website but could find no renewal price so decided to opt...

try malwarebytes, it’s the best freeware virus scaner i’ve used. Idk about protection but it scans everything thoroughly.

Read full topic

item.description:
@laurent_248 wrote:

lmao windows vista- is a suicide, windows=really not safe. Windows 7 is more safe but all the other OS are more safe than windows, every kind of viruses are .exe and/or vbs, somme noobs use .bat. None of these are running on other machines and most of people use windows so they wont make a public hack for other OS. here’s some statistics on OS use I found here.

2011 Win7 Vista Win2003 WinXP W2000 Linux Mac
January 31.1% 8.6% 1.0% 45.3% 0.2% 5.0% 7.8%

item.title: Standard for Anti-Virus
item.dc:creator: @laurent_248 laurent 248
item.description:
@laurent_248 wrote:

[quote=“Javafire, post:9, topic:382565”][quote author=laurent 248 link=topic=478359.msg3501250#msg3501250 date=1297740372]

hey java you weren’t something like 195 rep few minutes ago?

Anyway the best is AVG free, it’s not invasive but it protect fine internet+Computer.

rep means nothing to me, honestly i’d rather have none or locked.

AVG is very suspicious to me, the owner has been into alot of trouble for getting in with limwire and torrenting sites.

They did it because they knew that the most of hackers spread in torrents and stuff like limewire so they wanted to protect it. That’s not bad, because they know that everyone download stuff like this and the mission of this company is protect the computers and make the hacks more difficult. I know, they got in trouble but I don’t care, it do the job.

or because they can prfit off of putting them behind bars like limewire does.

Maybe but they reduced the virus chances of some of the most infected websites.
[/quote]
yes but does it have rootkit and botnet protection, i have used almost every virus-protection software there is, avg just seems like crap, and is a waste of money to buy premium.[/quote]

Yeah but anyway people who download AVG just don’t an invasive AntiVirus. The AVG pro is invasive like any other.

Read full topic
